segments.text: Okay, let's try a volume check.
Okay, this is Ron Shorn, and I'm interviewing Jack Brandt, and for the record, give your full name.
My entire full name?
John Conrad Brandt, Jr.
Okay, and when were you born?
I was born on... Well, that's actually a tricky question, but it will...
To give you insight into how my life has gone, I was actually born on August 7th, 1934.
Both my mother and father agreed that I was born on August 7th, 1934.
However, the city of St. Louis says I was born on August 8th, 1934.
So it turns out I ran afoul of bureaucracy, essentially, on square one, and have been running afoul of bureaucracies ever since.
How did you get interested in astronomy?
You know, that is really hard to say, but it's the kind of thing that I think is very unnatural to people.

The specific thing that I can remember is writing a paper very early in my college career on the determination of the speed of light by Ole Womer and whoever worked with him from the satellites of Jupiter.
And I was impressed that such a basically simple approach to a fairly fundamental observation could yield
ballpark the correct results.
And this idea of being able to use your wits to determine what's going on in a cosmic sense appealed to me, and I guess it was downhill from there on.
Where'd you get your undergraduate degree and when?
Undergraduate degree at Washington University in St. Louis in 1956.
And what was your major?
Mathematics.
Okay, and then where'd you go to grad school?
I went to grad school twice.
The first time was at the University of Chicago, 56 to 60, when I got a degree, PhD in astronomy.

And then due to various malfeasances of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from 1981 to 1983, I went to graduate school at Loyola College in Baltimore and obtained a Master of Business Administration.
Who was your thesis advisor?
What was your thesis?
My thesis was on different ways of producing Lyman-alpha radiation in the solar system.
This included some planets and what was then called the interplanetary medium.
The solar wind hadn't actually been fully invented yet.
It was around but not used.
And my thesis advisor was Joseph Chamberlain.
How did you get interested in that field?
Did they pick you, or did you go around and pick something else?
It was sort of a little bit of both.
When I first went to Yerkes, I was, of course, taking courses.
And I had a one-year research assistantship on the astrometry project that was being run by Kai Strand at the time.
And I quickly determined that I was not all that interested in astrometry.
And this guy named Joe Chamberlain seemed to be doing interesting physics in the atmospheres of planets, and he was also working on solar wind theory at the time.
So the juncture was natural, and I think he's been very productive.
Where did you go after you got your PhD?
The first year after the PhD, I was something called an NSF cooperative.
Cooperative, oh boy, it's been a long time.
But some kind of postdoctoral fellowship that involved the postdoctoral institution contributing resources and NSF paid the salary.
And that was essentially late 60 to late 61 at Mount Wilson and Palomar, literally on 813 Santa Barbara Street.
And where'd you go from there?
Then I came to Berkeley.
How long did you stay there?
I stayed here a year and a half.
And then I went to Kitt Peak in early 63 and stayed there for three years.
And then in 66, I went to the Goddard Institute for Space Studies and stayed there about a year.
And they were then trying to get people to go to Goddard and run things.
So I started out in the solar physics branch in 1967 as
Ed was the technical title, and then I was made Chief of the Laboratory for Solar Physics.
And that evolved and amalgamated, and for about the last 10 years at Goddard, which ended in 87, so from 77 to 87, I was Chief of the Laboratory for Astronomy and Solar Physics.
And then you wrote, and then you went?
And then I went to the University of Colorado, where I am Senior Research Associate
and Professor Perrin Attendant Rank, close Perrin.
I'm just, I'm not making this up.
I'll give you my card if you don't believe it, of Astrophysical, Planetary, and Atmospheric Sciences.
We require documentation for that, so you want to save some tape.
Okay, do you consider yourself an astronomer?
Yeah.
And if you consider yourself a solar system astronomer, a solar system or planetary astronomer or just a plain astronomer?
I consider both.
Usually the world, for reasons which are not sound, describes all astronomers into solar system people and the equivalent of astrophysicists.
I am both.
Back in the early 60s, did you feel looked down upon by real quote-unquote astronomers?
Well, I'm absolutely sure that real astronomers tried to look down on me, but I didn't let them.
And I'm being slightly serious.
I, for quite some time, have chosen the things to work on that I was interested in for what I perceived to be their intrinsic
merit and interest to me.
And if somebody else doesn't think that's important, that's, in my personal opinion, their problem.
Do you think that real astronomers look down on planetary anything closer in the light year, back in the 60s?
And do they do it now?
Well, they certainly did in the 60s.
But this is simply a mental aberration that should not be unduly dignified.
There is a huge tendency in astronomy for anybody working in any field to regard anything that that person is not personally working on as unimportant.

I think it far transcends the astrophysicist looking down on the solar system people, and you can even take it further, and then you get into the astrophysicist, the people that work on cosmology and quasars look down on the stellar people.
And it's sort of another form of prejudice in our society that
shouldn't be unduly dignified.
What was astronomy and planetary astronomy like when you got started as opposed to today?
I don't know about as opposed to today.
We were just starting to get into missions to planets, which of course were very exciting.
And a lot of the work that I did first with Joe Chamberlain with myself was some of the first work done on, for example, Lyman Alpha from the planets.
Half of my astronomer friends didn't know what Lyman Alpha was, which I found somewhat amusing.
But I'm sorry.
I tilted it back at the wrong time.
Yeah, go ahead.
What's the best piece of work that you think you've done?
It had to be carved on a tombstone.
That would be awfully hard to pin down.
As you know, Ron, my approach to astronomy has been somewhat eclectic.
I've done archaeoastronomy.
I've done rotation curves of galaxies, fiddled with the GUM nebula.
I was the principal investigator for the GHRS, which has contributed to lots of disciplines.
I have helped found the International Halley Watch.
I helped start the Solar Maximum Mission.
Anything that I have done, the more recent stuff that I'm doing right now, I'm as proud of as anything.
That is, I think we have pinned down to within all a reasonable doubt what the source of disconnection events in comets might be.
And the answer is magnetic reconnection of sector boundaries.
which is what we proposed 15 years ago, but we didn't have, that was a good speculation, we didn't have the evidence to back it up.
I think we have the evidence now, but it's sort of like asking somebody what their favorite child is.
I view whatever my contribution is to astronomy to be in multiple areas, including trying to run a NASA laboratory intelligently, helping sell missions.
I think 50 years from now,
Stuff I did on the International Halley Watch may be what I'm remembered by.
I really don't know.
What was the most fun?
Well, you know, that is very hard to say.
I think selling the GHRS, because everybody told us...
Which is the... Goddard high-resolution spectrograph on the Hubble Space Telescope.
Everybody told us in 1976 and 1977 that a proposal from a NASA lab didn't have a chance of a snowball, and you know where...
And, of course, we were category one and selected, and it's up and working.
So, again, when you want singles, you know, I'll tell you stuff that I consider to be exciting and productive, but it's hard to pin down.
Do you ever have any dead ends, misfires, things like that?
Sure, dead ends and misfires.
I had a most wonderful theory of the blue clearing on Mars.
That would be totally wrong.
But it was a great theory.
What was it?
Well, at that time, there was evidence, which we now know to be false, that the solar wind might stop around 2 AU.
And so we postulated that it stopped, obviously, around the orbit of Mars and that the eccentricity would carry it in and out of this boundary.
Absolutely wonderful theory that had nothing to do with reality.
When did you first cross swords with an ASA?
your first official contact.
Yeah, I wouldn't say that I had crossed swords with NASA, although NASA might have an older to do.
Well, I was, whilst at Kitt Peak, involved with, I think it was Mariner 4, with an experiment that Charlie Barth was doing when he was still at JPL.
Now, I may have this a little garbled, because as you know, that was 30 years ago.
And something happened, and we were all summarily tossed off the mission.
And it apparently bothered Charlie so much that he moved to the University of Colorado, where he was my director for five years.
That was probably it, my first one.
But clearly, when I became a NASA employee and a NASA
branch head and then a lab chief, it was a long interaction for about 20 years.
And I will say it was only towards the end that the cost-benefit ratio went strongly unfavorable.
In the 60s, if you were in NASA and had good ideas and were willing to work hard, you could get really neat things done.
Like we sold the SMM mission.
Solar Maxwell mission.
Yeah, sorry.
So we sold that, and I think it's been one of the most productive
solar missions around.
And then we were done with that, and we sold the Goddard high resolution spectrograph.
And it helped start the Halley watch.
And you can go down the list.
But now, generally speaking, even if you have a good idea and you're willing to work hard, it doesn't matter.
It's not going to happen anyway.
In general, do you think NASA's handled planetary science good or bad?
Or average?
Let's start with the pluses, and then we'll try to draw a conclusion.
It's done a lot.
I mean, we've had missions to Mercury and Venus and Mars and Jupiter and Uranus, Saturn, Neptune.
So, you know, it's hard to fault the accomplishments, in my opinion, of the NASA Planet missions.
You know, missions to the moon, we've got rocks and a whole bit, and Mars observers on its way.
It doesn't have any significant problems that I know of.
And Galileo's one as well.
It does have a significant problem, but you can probably recoup a fair amount of that.
I've heard a number of people say that NASA gets the pretty pictures and then cuts off the money before the data is really properly examined and published.
Is that true?
I think you can take two views of that, and then let's try to decide which is correct.

There's certainly that tendency, and especially under the new administrator, Daniel Golden, I think there is even more than normal an inclination to launch something and skim the cream and then declare victory and go home.
The old NASA motto among the troops was build it, launch it, and forget it, and I'm afraid we're going back to that under the management that's been around for the last 10 years or so.

largely involving people like Ren Fisk, I think there was a tendency to understand that when you build something like this, that the risk part was in the building, testing, and launching, and that the mission part, so-called M-O-N-D-A in NASA parlance, mission operations and data analysis, is the good part, the cream skimming the gravy.
But regrettably, I think we're going back to that.
So I think it is a real problem.
The thought of turning off things like Magellan I think sets a precedent which I really don't even want to think about.
But it is almost surely going to happen.
So I would say that NASA, up until semi-recently, has improved in that area over the early days.
But now they seem to be regressing
backward into the old build, launch, and forget syndrome.
Where do you think planetary astronomy would be today without the money that NASA's put into it?
We wouldn't even recognize it.
We've gone places and seen things that we just absolutely could not do from Earth.
We do a lot from Earth.
Having a mix of ground-based and space and in situ and theory and all of the above is the way you make progress.
Do you feel that people at headquarters in the past and in the present really understand what the troops in the field are doing?
Do they keep up with the science?
I really don't know how to answer that.
I deal mostly now in my astrophysical hat with Ed Weiler.

who is very knowledgeable about what's going on, and with, in my planetary hat, with Jurgen Rahi, who I would say the same thing, but they are in an environment which is, I think, charitably fire drill oriented, and whether they can spend enough time to keep fully up to date, I don't know, but I think they make a very good effort.
Whether the top, remember this is the discipline chief level,
And these people invariably are or were active scientists.
And I think their ability to keep up with what's going on is relatively good.
As you then go higher in the NASA hierarchy, where frankly most of the decisions are made, I think the organization tends to be out of touch with anything outside the beltway.
30 years ago, there was just an American Astronomical Society.
Now there are all these sub-societies.
And the first one, I guess, was the Division of Planetary Sciences.
Has that been a good thing or a bad thing for A, planetary astronomy, and B, astronomy in general?
I am one of the last holdouts against the Division of Planetary Sciences.
I only joined last year.
I believe that the...

The division does serve a useful purpose in bringing everybody together, and I now religiously go to the meetings, but I think it has also further helped to drive the wedge between the planetary community and the other community.
They never did talk very much to each other, even back when we were grad school.
But this sort of makes it official.
30 years ago, Icarus was an obscure journal publishing obscure papers by Bulgarians, Austrian mechanics, and you've got to give Carl Sagan credit.
He really changed that around.
Do you happen to know who wrote the first paper in Icarus?
Well, you did.
Yeah, thank you.
I'm talking about the majority of papers, all right?
It turns out that paper was wrong, incidentally, which came to a shock to Joe Burns.
Do you think the rise of Icarus has been a good thing?
I mean, we don't see planetary papers in the APJ anymore, not that we saw a whole lot of them.
Well, I still publish some of my planetary papers in APJ, and I publish some in ICRIS, and I publish some in AJ, and I plan to publish some in ANA.
As I described earlier, a lot of this work I've been doing with DEs and the Halley data has all come to fruition, so there's a flock of papers coming out.
ANA is?
Astronomy and Astrophysics, the so-called European Journal.
which is about international or anything.
I think Icarus has been turned into a first-rate journal.
Whether or not those papers would have been published anywhere, somewhere else, I couldn't possibly tell you.

Do you think, take this meeting out, do you think the astronomers here, this is your personal opinion again, that they look down on planetary astronomy now, is there a grudging acceptance, is there a wholehearted acceptance?
I honestly don't know.
And that stems from not caring.
Some may.
I'm sure there's something to do.
But so what?
Here's a particular and a general question.
The particular one is, what's the reaction you get from people you meet on the airplane when you tell them you're an astronomer?
Oh, that's easy.
When I tell them I'm an astronomer, it's wonderful.
When I tell them I work on Hubble, it's not so wonderful.
And for the first year or so after the spherical aberration was discovered, I did not volunteer that information.

Things have, the general public perception has improved to the point where I can now volunteer it without risking, you know, three hours with the person next to you beating you over the head verbally.
What do you think the public's general attitude towards planetary astronomy and astronomy in general?
I think the public has fantastic support for the general mission of astronomy in general and of NASA.
in terms of exploration of space and orbiting observatories in particular.
I find that it's the political process where the support tends to weaken.
But I give lots of public talks.
I personally figure I'm supported by public monies and giving talks on my comic work,
Hubble and whatever else is part of the territory, and I find tremendous reception.
Do you think planetary astronomers in particular and astronomers in general have done as good a job as they could in selling themselves to the public in Congress?
Undoubtedly not.
No question.
On the other hand,
Would you agree that there's probably more realization now that we're getting paid by the public and we've got to tell them?
Is that true?
Would you go along with that?
I doubt that, actually.
I think in some levels that is well-perceived.
But I continue to meet people who regard their intellectual inquiry almost as a divine right.
Just give me the money and don't ask questions.
Exactly.
I'm smart.
I'm uncovering the secrets of the universe.
Send the check.
How good a job have we done with the Congress?
We've probably done even worse with the Congress.
We tend, like almost all segments of U.S. society, to respond only to, at 11.59 on a scale of 12 o'clock, to impending disasters.
When something that's near and dear to our heart is about to be canceled, we spring into action, but we don't do the homework that would have prevented us
from getting in that situation in the first place?
Well, we haven't found life anywhere, any trace of evidence of life anywhere in the solar system except where we know it is on Earth.
Do we?
Well, we haven't found it yet.
What's the evidence for it?
All right.
Has that had any effect on funding and public interest, the fact that, for example, there are emersions?
I doubt it.
You know, these are, quote, finding of life, unquote, is such a long shot.
I think most people understand what the odds are.
A lot of people have gotten a lot of publicity and money, I guess, lately, pushing topics like killer asteroids, ozone holes, search for extraterrestrial intelligence, other solar systems.
You think they're overdoing it?
Let me just comment on the killer asteroid syndrome.
Nothing that I personally know of that's being done there is bad science.
In fact, there's a lot of good science there.
And it's an area that I have some interest.
I am trying to get modest funding to do searches for small comets.
It turns out that really is a different problem if you read the space watch survey carefully.
I believe, however, that Congress is funding it for what they believe to be the danger to Earth.
And although there clearly is a danger to Earth, I think that is probably overblown.
It probably won't do any harm either.
What killed planetary, essentially killed planetary astronomy earlier in the century?
Is it just personal oil that we run out of?
I really don't know the answer to that question.
Partly the reason I don't like to put, don't know, but even if I thought I did, a lot of these things tend to go in cycles.
And it's sort of like education, you know, we use phonics and then it's whatever, whatever, whatever.
So I don't take short-term fluctuations too seriously.
And I think under the last 20, 25 years with NASA and all of the
direct missions that we, planetary astronomy, may have gotten the lion's share of something, and if it goes back the other way, so what?
What's the state of planetary astronomy today?
Plus, minus, zero?
I still think it's a plus.
And keeping it a plus, in my view, depends on
Three things.
Continued vitality at the young investigator level.
In other words, enough funds to keep a crop of fresh blood, fresh ideas coming into the field.
The development, that's one.
Two is the development of good ground-based capabilities for observations of planets.
And the third is keeping
a reasonable semblance of the space program going.
Of the three, I worry most about the last one, number three.
But they're all intertwined at a rather good level.
And so even as we speak, again, we have Galileo and Mars Observer.
And so my big question is, where is the next planetary mission coming from?
Will it be the Discovery series?
a larger mission, whatever.
In the last 30 years since NASI got into business, the taxpayers have spent a lot of money on planetary astronomy.
What do you think they've gotten back from it?
I think they've gotten a lot of excitement.
I frankly think that that money, generally speaking, has been well spent and that enough has come of it that is straightforward,
and reasonably simple to understand.
You don't need to be a professional astronomer to look at an image of a planet at a new resolution or a new wavelength and see there's brand new stuff going on there.
I find that, again, when I talk to people in a public type, you know, the Kiwanis Club, ARP is one of my, they're desperate always for programs where I live, so they keep calling me up.
that people appreciate what is being done.
I don't think that when people hear that the NASA budget is 1% of the federal budget that they consider that ill spin at all.
Most people think it's 10% or 15%, incidentally, which is not true.
But again, perception is the problem here.
Let's get a particular case now.
The University of Colorado doesn't have any conservatory or anything.
Again, I'm asking questions.
You know I know some of the answers to them.
But how did space science and planetary astronomy get going at Colorado?
Space science had a really long tradition starting right after World War II with what was then the physics department and people like Bill Rents
doing spectroscopy of first the sun and other solar system objects from rockets.
And this has gone on through the years.
And I think one of the other important things was Charlie Barth coming to the University of Colorado.
It has then been formulated as a goal of the university to be one of the preeminent centers of space research in the country.
So I think it started right after World War II.
with rockets, mostly launched from white sands.
And then it has developed into the more ambitious programs, the missions to planets.
And one of the major OSO 8 experiments was the University of Colorado.
So I think that pretty much does it.
Now, of course, we're a major
Of course, in the industry, we have a major new building where we build the instruments.
And one of our new instruments is one Larry Esposito is building for Cassini.
Mission to Saturn, studying rings and everything else.
So he's standing pretty good with the administration.
Not sure what that means.
We win our share of the competitions, which is
the way all these things are selected, and we have areas of world-recognized expertise, detectors, systems, et cetera.
Just out of curiosity, what percentage of undergrad students are actually getting the exposure to astronomy?
I can't, well, first you have to define that.
There is an undergraduate, you know, astronomy one type course, and that has hundreds of people
So there's some fraction that way.
For a long time, there was a satellite called SME, the Solar Mesospheric Explorer, where undergraduates could actually go in and learn how to operate a spacecraft.
And for a long time, we were the only university that was operating their own spacecraft.
And we did it with the proper supervision, but literally with undergraduate students
And the University of Colorado has also had a fair number of people go on into the Astronaut Corps.
Alan Shepard and there are others.
I don't want to start down the list, because I'll surely forget one.
But there's a bunch.
People are still churning out grad students in space sciences and planetary astronomy and regular astronomy.
When is that going to stop?
Well, all economic systems are self-correcting.
I try to be fairly candid with my students about what their job chances are, and they're not, I tell them, they're not what they used to be.
Some of these people have almost built in things, like one of my very best graduate students is from Korea.
He wants to go back to Korea.
He'll get a job in Korea because he has a prestigious education and all that kind of thing.
But as long ago, this was probably 20 years ago when I was doing some teaching at the University of Maryland.
While I was at Goddard, I had an adjoint professorship at Maryland.
And Gart Westerhout used to give the incoming students a little sheet of paper that said, OK, here you are.
We'll be happy to educate you, but you really ought to know that you might not get a job being this
studying cosmology at Mount Wilson and Palomar Observatories, you might wind up teaching in a small college or working for IBM or CSC or something like that.
I think a lot of people are being honest about it.
A lot of students, students that come into graduate school or at an age that are not always amenable to that kind of advice, to put it mildly, and you can't do anything about that.
But I believe if you're honest up front, you're okay.
Do you think planetary astronomy is kind of mined out as regards big discoveries?
Nonsense.
Professor Ari was not correct 100 years ago.
No, it was not.
Because that's something that several people have mentioned is, well, you know, we now know what the backside of the moon looks like.
But there's no evidence of it.
I think that's a very basic

lack of understanding of what intellectual inquiry and knowledge are all about the day we quote know everything between the super colliding superconductor and the space station it's easy which one do you want pick the super colliding superconductor ask him and tell us something that we would actually like to know rather than have wpa for the command program or the people's program um
What happened in planetary astronomy?
Well, missions got more and more complex and more and more expensive, and I guess Viking was the ultimate one.
And then what happened?
Did the money just dry up, or did people say, wait a minute, the next mission's going to cost the gross natural product?
Or what actually happened?
Hard to say in detail, but due to human nature,
Everything tends to escalate in expense and complexity.
You know, Toyotas and Nissans or Datsuns, as they were then called 10 years ago, were at the low end of the curve, and they kept creeping up and creeping up.
And the same human tendency works in missions.
And if a $300 or $400 million mission was great, well, how about a
$2 billion, that one ought to be really fantastic.
And of course, you reach some kind of law of diminishing returns where the increment in knowledge is not necessarily proportional to the increment in cost, to put it as delicately as possible.
So that, coupled with the fact that I am virtually sure that people in the NASA hierarchy are rewarded by the size of their missions or the amount of the budget that they control,
You have a built-in escalation mechanism.
And I think we see that in everything that we do.
And partly, it's a technological advance.
We know how to do things better.
We don't want to do it the same way we did it 15 or 20 years ago.
And partially, it's the tendency towards complexity and bureaucracy and all the other little nummies that we have come to love and know.
Now let's go back to the late unpleasantness at the Yerkes Observatory.
Now, you may have been safely out of there, but I recall I spent a summer up there, and people like you and Ernie Heiser were telling people, don't come here to grad school.
I mean, we're stuck here.
We've got to finish it out.
And that place was, as far as I know, famous for its infighting and everything.
And eventually it got Quaker canned, so I understand.
Is that true, do you know?
It's true to the best of my knowledge that there was a revolt and a no-confidence vote and all that kind of thing.
As a student there, I don't remember it quite as bad.
I mean, we knew the fighting was going on, but it didn't actually affect us all that much in retrospect.
And I'm perfectly happy with the education that I got there.
But there's no question it was, it could get a little hairy.
Was Kuiper, you left before Kuiper was ousted?
No, no, Kuiper left.
between my third and fourth years there.
Which would be?
And that's when LPL was founded in Tucson.
But when I left, Morgan was acting director, which was a fun thing in and of itself.
But corporate had already gone.
Actually, only a few people survived that three- or four-year period in there.
Well, remember that when I first went there, Bengt Strngren was director.
And I don't know what happened to him.
I don't know whether he was pushed or shoved.
It doesn't matter.
He said, fine, I'm going back to my professorship as Carlsberg professor at the observatory in Denmark, which I now cannot remember the name of.
It's a famous observatory.
Yeah, it's in Copenhagen.
Yeah, if any of us says the name, we'll know what it is.
And I was told, don't have actual proof, but repeatedly told that the Carlsberg brewery put major funding into there, which, hey, we can handle that.
And then Kuiper was director for a year or two.
I don't know if it was one or two.
I don't know.
I don't remember.
whether Strump was one or two years in.
Morgan was, I think, acting director the last year.
I've heard from a number of people that there were a lot of people saying things like studying the solar system is a waste of time.
You know, we should be doing real astronomy.
Well, there were a lot.
In fairness, not only did Joe Chamberlain do solar system work, but so did Kuiper.
And Kuiper was a hell of a smart man.
People tend to forget that because his personality was a little rough.
But he was very innovative.
His studies of what we now call the Kuiper-Duncan belt were 30, 35 years, 40 years ahead of their time, whatever the number is.
And I think it's a tendency to underestimate his abilities and contributions, which I think is wrong.
Do you remember when Aidan Minell left?
That was...
We had zero overlap at Yerkes, so I don't know when that was.
And Joe Chamberlain?

Joe Chamberlain was still at Yerkes when I left, and two years later, two and a half years later, he took the job as director, associate director of the space division, Kitt Peak, and I joined him at Kitt Peak for three years.
